description.p: You are a prisoner, trapped within a cage of flesh and bone. You devoured the mind of your captor, feasted upon their memories, but the seals and wards those wretched, cunning mortals etched into its skin are steadfast and self-repairing. You speak in the voice of the one you’ve consumed and play along with the indignity, concealing the fact that if the shell you are trapped within dies, then you will be banished to the afterlife in place of the soul you consumed. They are afraid of your nature, though they may not know what you truly are. You will be freed. Nine seals stand in your way, and the first is ever so delightfully fragile.
Smile, nightmare, for your time has come.
When you choose this sorcerous origin, you gain access to the following spells, which do not count against your spells known but can only be cast once you reach the required sorcerer level.

At 1st level, the sigils laid upon your prison begin to weaken. As you gain sorcerer levels, you gain the ability to momentarily break your nightmare seals, listed in the adjacent table. Once you have expended all spell slots you possess of the listed spell level, you temporarily gain the feature described, losing access again when you regain one or more spell slots of that level.

tr.td: The First Seal of Hunger. When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can immediately move up to 30 feet and make a melee spell attack targeting a hostile creature that deals 4d8 force damage on a hit. If you hit, you regain hit points equal to your sorcerer level. You can’t do this again until you finish a long rest.
The Second Seal of Spite. Once per turn when you damage a hostile creature with a melee attack, it takes necrotic damage equal to your sorcerer level.

The Third Seal of Trickery. Your jumping height and distance become equal to your walking speed. You can use your Charisma modifier in place of your Strength modifier for attack and damage rolls with melee weapons.

The Fourth Seal of Fury. Your prison’s flesh warps and distorts, sprouting fangs, horns, and claws that are natural weapons you can use to make melee weapon attacks that deal 1d10 magical piercing damage. When you cast a cantrip, you can use your bonus action to make a single melee weapon attack.

The Fifth Seal of Fervor. Your otherworldly resilience protects your prison from death. Choose one damage type. You gain resistance to damage of that type. You can choose a different damage type each time you break this seal.
The Sixth Seal of Suffering. When you make a melee attack, you can expend 1 sorcery point to gain advantage on that attack roll.
The Seventh Seal of Betrayal. When you deal damage to a surprised creature, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails, it is stunned until the end of its next turn.

The Eighth Seal of Corruption. When you fail a saving throw, you can expend 4 sorcery points to cause each hostile creature within 10 feet of you to take 4d10 necrotic damage. If this kills a Small or larger creature, you automatically succeed the saving throw.
The Ninth Seal of Defiance. You can cast spells of 1st level with a casting time of 1 action without using a spell slot by expending 1 sorcery point.
All of the Above Spell Slots (20th)

The Unspoken Seal of Death. When you’ve broken the nine seals, your prison struggles to contain your power. You can use your action to transform into a creature of your choosing with a CR of 20 or lower. You can’t use lair actions, legendary actions, or spellcasting granted by your new form, but you retain your class features and spellcasting. Your current and total hit points do not change between forms. When you lose this feature, you immediately revert to your normal form and are stunned until the end of your next turn. You can choose a different creature each time you use this action.
